comments.commentBody:
Mechanism of injury, Savard was not wearing a mouth guard when he was hit in the jaw, allowing the transfer of energy to the skullbase. The assessment doctors at UPMC do not do anything to prevent this type of injury from occuring or identify longterm symptoms created by this trauma to temoporal mandibular joint health. Many Bruin and NHL/AHL players have benefited from a corrective oral appliance developed with the Patriots and now the focus of both the NFL and the U.S Military. Duxbury H.S. students were the subject of a recently published study, that explains how a corrective oral appliance will help support the jaw, reducing the risk of further injury. Prior to play, assessment of the jaw should be manditory for all MIAA participants, the NFL and NHL are already investigating this protocol. www.mahercor.com

I found this victory to be in general not impressive,considering it was at home against a weak opponent who did not have much to play for
Aside from a few big plays the Jets still dont inspire much confidence

Yankees co-chairman Hank Steinbrenner said. "Some of these players are wealthier than their bosses." So what, Hank? These players produce a socially useful product; you produce nothing. Derek Jeter got to where he is by hard work and great talent. Jeter brings fans into the ballpark, you don't. Jeter struggled to get to where he is.You were born into your position in life. It is Derek Jeter who givesYOU an income, not the other way around.

How bout the yankees giving Jeter the many millions more he is asking with the stipulation
that he give the excess millions in free or reduced tickets to poor or lower middle class
families because drugs, money, players, managers, fans have destroyed the game so that
only richer people can go to the games?

I absolutely loved my stay Sultania. The hotel is very clean and tidy with a great location. It is about a 10 minute walk to reach all the main attractions in Sultanahmet: Hagia Sofia, Tokapi Palace, the Blue Mosque, etc. There are lots of great restaurants and places for shopping. It has a wonderful receptionist, Selcuk, who was very helpful. The rest of the staff was also very friendly and helpful. The room is comfortable and comes with all amenities. There is a breakfast buffet included, which is also served on the rooftop terrace when it’s not raining. The hotel even offers free wireless internet. The price was very reasonable and I would definitely recommend it. When your stay is longer than 3 nights you’ll get free airport transfers when booking on the hotel website.
www.hotelsultania.com
At last, a story on the Jets winning a game without the usual "they shouldn't have won" commentary from the NYT.
Fly to NY we will show you confidence, enjoy your Raiders!
Nostradamus with a crooked sense of humor!!!Poor Lions and Cowboys!!!LOL

#9 m flagg: The other team at 9-2 is allowing 290+ yards a game...so maybe no one this year reminds you of the '72 Fins...one team will win in February anyway...my guess is it'll be the Jets, the Pats, the Steelers, the Colts, the Ravens, the Eagles, the Falcons, the Saints, the Giants or the Packers...and right now, your guess is as good as mine as to which one of those 10 it will be...attempting to make that forecast by looking at fine details of late November performance probably will not repay the effort...

fyi
I am a jet fan
have been since 67
grew up in NY
never rooted for LA teams
I just wish the jets could put up one solid 60 minute effort without mistakes or relying on a few big plays to make me think they can win 3 or 4 playoff games against good teams and win the super bowl

The Mandarin Oriental in Hong Kong is the place to stay if money is no object http://www.hongkonghotel.com/mandarin-oriental-hong-kong.htm. The hotel is as iconic as Raffles in Singapore. Lunchtime buffet is the most spectacular I've encountered although the full buffet inc port did cost $250 per head!

@Chaos130, I'm sure everyone is totally bored with it!  Who started this, anyhow?  I think it was our early-rising friend over in Hadlyme.  But when a challenge is issued I can't let it go.  If I manage to create something, I'll send a photo to Jim or Patrick...  BTW, don't count on getting Chinese food on Thanksgiving unless you live near a decent-sized city.  Which I don't.  Oh, well!

Oh, for heaven's sake!  From now on I'm going to type my comments in Word and paste them in so I can do it again when they disappear.  (I was already annoyed - all the Chinese restaurants around here are closed!)  Anyhow, if I do create a MHP cocktail worthy of sharing I'll send a photo to Jim or Patrick.  I am honored to have been nominated for this important assignment.  If we bored you, just remember - fivethirtyam started it!
Very late to this, but had to laugh...what do you do with an English degree? Go to law school and then teach...this semester was indeed Plessy v. Ferguson.

Have been on the road again -- doing the puzzle on the NJ Transit this time, and finishing (no googles!) it on the way back to NYC with a few well-deserved Thanksgiving burps. Warning to all: you do NOT want to be in NYC's Penn Station at noon on Thanksgiving Day. All the parade watchers want to go home .. at the same time. So I'm late, but nevertheless .... FWIW

A very un-Thursday-like Thursday offering -- more like a weak Friday. From the 48D fill I wonder if I'm being gotten at again this week ... :) ... nah. That would have been a 19A.

Believe it or not, 38A was a gimme -- from a long-remembered high school history project about the Supereme Court. But now I can't remember why.

Curious coincidence: 46A and 60D. BTW did you know that 5 regulation 750 ml wine bottles just about maes up a US gallon? Something similar in a puzzle of a few weeks back.

Learned something after a google curiosity fill: the generic name for acetylene.

Just now got around to Chaos130 @ 19 on Thursday's blog column post. So now I'm being mooted, hm? Hmpf! :)

ok, now you've got my interest piqued. This is an interesting R&D issue but since I need to watch my blood sugar I can only verbalize and not partake.

Regarding the yellow, I'm not sure how standard that is, but mango sorbet is not it. It seems to be the same kind of yellow that NYC taxis are graced with. A bit like French's mustard too. Could you put that in a cocktail? (Nah.)

Ummm -- how about peach sorbet? Now that would definitely work. Titrate it with vodka or white rum to get the right viscosity.

BTW, licorice and fruit go a long way. There was a candy in the '40s and '50s that was a cube about 2/3 of an inch on a side made up of layers of licorice and fruit somethings, looked like a zebra on LSD. So I am sure raspberry and licorice will go well.

FWIW. I'm posting this in the Friday blog without peeking.

Oh, I thought the theme was Mark, The Ice Station Prisoner. I,too, got the theme answers relatively easy, but flubbed a few things. Guessed a bear did in Adonis, no go out of bounds and danced the bugaloo. I writhed on 1Across for a long time and it was my last entry. Patsy Cline had a fabuloues voice and her songs are easy for me to recall.
The puzzle was worth the one year wait. Thank you Gary Z. Steinmehl

The fun part about Friday and Saturday is that your defenses are up. Crawl spaces is probably pools, right? No, better wait to be sure, get a cross or two before putting pen to paper. That slows down the solve, but increases the pleasure when (and if) you finish.

Thanks for a good one, Gary. Hope everyone had a great mature poult day.
I don't see why Shortz has to go and alienate everyone under 85 with puzzles like this. Doing this puzzle was like pulling teeth.

A very good, challenging puzzle. The NW corner was the last I filled in. I was about to give up when I suddenly realized that "grow together" could be KNIT! After that it all fell into place.

I learned that BORAX is used in making synthetic gems - a brand-new fact to me. Also new to me was learning that young turkeys are POULTS.

At first for "one way to love" I had TRULY, but I couldn't make it work. MADLY works.

The only item I wasn't pleased with was GRIPPER, clued as "vise." I think of a vise as a kind of clamp. I thought GRIPPER was a bit off; it made me think of a clothing fastener. That was, however, a very minor nit.

All in all, this puzzle gave me a lot of pleasure, especially when I finally solved 21 Across.

As I write this, at 2:30 am while suffering from a tad too much Thanksgiving, there are no entries yet.  But I am 100% positive that many of the astute solver/bloggers will tell us that this was "too easy for a Friday", because Mr. Happy Pencil popped out at the 9:59 mark, and that is highly unusual for me.  All of my guesses turned out to be correct, so I'm feeling rather smug.  Thanks! I needed that!  Now, could someone please pass the Tums?

Problem 2:
(repeating my post since not sure it went through)
One elevator.
Capacity = max number of stops
required (5 or 6 as the case may be)
numeric keypad on the inside of elevator and outside on the floors)
Selection of floor punched in by passengers. Memory register has the same limitation =capacity.
If there is room, there will be a free slot.
Elevator will stop at floors from where passengers punched in (according to whether an upward or downward trip is indicated by the choice). And also at floors as per the register.
Multiple passengers for the same floor will make possible additional registry entries but alas no room, wait for the next ride buddy. Also you need to punch in again. (biometrics can make service better by allowing computing waiting status)

"They realize there are economic consequences with taking all of the equity out of your house and using it like an ATM machine.”

Really!? I realized that some years ago when a law allowing loans against home equity was being debated in Texas. [Before that, your home really was your castle, provided you paid your (low) property taxes.]
Couldn't convince the BB I was arguing with then; wonder if he's learned by now....
To mousum and squirrel conceits, I like the Dostoyevski more!--B. Badinov

Consumption can never be the solution to anything. it is the central problem. americans created the wrong model based purely on consumptiona and more consumption - introduced concepts like "planned obsolesence". All products built in the US are expected to be obsolete in max 2-3 years. New model brought out of the same stuff - no real change - only cosmetic changes. people fooled by marketing and advertising to buy things they do not need.
how long can this model succeed. it has to fail.
now chinese are being foolish to adopt this model.
our society can survive as a healthy one only if we get out of silly and stupid "per capita " measurement of everything under the sun.
